column9: As a nurse, I have really seen a dramatic effect in my geriatric patients on Opana. On the one hand, this med seems to relieve chronic back and joint pain far more effectively at lower and less frequent doses than other narcotic analgesics especially for those who have developed a tolerance to mess like Vicodin, Percocet, and morphine. Unfortunately, Opana is often prescribed for older patients who have respiratory and other deficiencies. I see adverse events like shallow breathing and increased sleep apnea all too often. Physicians seem to dismiss the correlation because the patient is pleased with pain relief. I must emphasize that the side effects are more severe and frequent which prompted my review here and I encourage people who are newly prescribed Opana to take it initially during waking hours with someone present to monitor for rapid adverse effects that may occur regardless of how/when you've been instructed to take it. Ultimately patient safety is the patient's responsibility. My experiences have been that many high tolerance people suffer severe side effects on Opana when they are accustomed to not experiencing such problems on other narcotic analgesics.
